newsitem.title: USA: NYMEX electric futures settle up, erase early loss.
newsitem.headline: NYMEX electric futures settle up, erase early loss.

text.p: NYMEX electricity futures settled higher Tuesday in a late jump, erasing early losses tied to light profit-taking, market sources said.
"It was just bouncing around," said a Houston trader, referring to the day's trading pattern.
He added physical prices in the western U.S. stayed firm today on still strong air-conditioning demand in the Southwest. "They've been very supportive."
November California-Oregon Border (COB) futures finished at $17.97 a megawatt hour (MWh), up two cents after hitting a session low of $17.65.
December COB also settled up two cents at $19.10. Other COB months ended up 10 cents higher than Monday's settlment.
November Palo Verde (PV) finished at $17.39 a MWh, up 14 cents after moving in a 25 cent range.
December PV settled up nine cents at $17.89. Deferred PV contracts ended unchanged to 40 cents higher.
Participants expected the electricity complex would test Tuesday's highs again Wednesday.
"If there's anywhere to go, it'll go higher," the Houston trader said.
NYMEX estimated 302 COB and 142 PV contracts were sold Tuesday.
The latest forecasts indicated the West would experience warmer to much-warmer than normal autumn weather next week.
